Helly-type theorem for eigenvectors
Alexandr Polyanskii
February 14, 2017
Abstract
We prove that if any 3d/2 or fewer elements of a nite family of linear operators
Kd  Kd (K is an arbitrary eld) have a common eigenvector then all operators
in the family have a common eigenvector. Moreover, 3d/2 cannot be replaced by
a smaller number. Also, we study the following problem, achieving partial results:
prove that if any l = O(d) or fewer elements of a nite family of linear operators
Kd  Kd have a common non-trivial invariant subspace then all operators in the
family have a common non-trivial invariant subspace.
Introduction
We denote the set of numbers {a, a + 1, . . . , b} by [a, b], where a  b are positive
integer numbers. Also, we use the following notation [b] := [1, b].
The well-known Hellys theorem [5] claims.
Theorem 1. Let F be a nite family of convex sets in Rd. If every d + 1 or fewer
elements of F intersects, then all the sets in the family F intersect.
There is an abundance of literature on Helly-type theorems, see for example
[1, 3, 4, 6, 8]. The aim of this work is to answer the following Helly-type question.
Problem 1. Let A be a nite family of linear operators Kd  Kd, where K is an
arbitrary eld and d  2. Find minimal k = HE(Kd) such that if any k or fewer
elements of A have a common eigenvector then there is a common eigenvector for
all operators in the family A.
The authors of [2] considered Problem 1 and gave the wrong proof of the fact
that HE(Kd) = d + 1 (see Theorem 5.1 in [2]). Our main result is the following
theorem.
Theorem 2. HE(Kd) = 3d/2 for an arbitrary eld K.
We prove Theorem 2 in Section 2.
